page.title: 07Changing Times continued
page.content: Postwar buildings enlarged the town. Traffic jams provided Sunday entertainment as people watched London bound traffic crawl through the town. Rationing kept small shops, and tradesmen delivered goods. In the 1960s Tonbridge began to expand to the West and East but mostly in the North. Supermarkets replaced small shops. Cinemas and dancing were popular. There was an excellent bus-service but traffic problems were considerable. Electric trains replaced steam trains making Tonbridge a popular commuter area. Several new schools were built. Today Tonbridge has reached the limit of its expansion. Small developments are replacing large old houses. The main developments are the Angel Centre providing supermarket, sports and exhibitions, the Industrial Estate and two By-passes built to ease traffic.
